title.narrative: Accelerating Change in Chipinge through Sustainable Solutions

description.narrative: The economic crisis in Zimbabwe has left the agriculture sector in tatters, shrinking supplies of inputs, inflating prices and dissolving vital infrastructure. None have been so hard hit by these events as rural farmers: declining yields and diminished purchasing power has created more than a million food insecure households. Under this program, improved food production is a result of increasing the output value per hectare of land by providing necessary inputs and improved resource management technology. Improved yields increase food security, raise household incomes, and facilitate the early recovery of rural communities. Re-establishing reliable agricultural input supply flows in target communities takes place at multiple points in the supply chain, from targeting resource-poor farmers with input vouchers and training rural agro-dealers, to linking agro-dealers to microfinance institutions. Sustainable, reliable access to inputs help farmers increase yields dramatically, improving household food consumption and generating income from the sale of surplus production. Long-term food security will be further enhanced by enabling farmers to adopt more productive and environmentally sustainable faming systems and low labor techniques. More specifically, this will involve introduction of conservation farming on a small but intensive scale, while introducing other technologies for improving yields, including horticultural production, on a larger scale by training Mercy Corps-mobilized farmer groups. Enabling resumption and intensification of vegetable gardening by integrating training with access to water extends food production to the dry season and generates household income. Training and capacity building of rural farmers though establishment of FAN clubs enables vulnerable households and communities to measurably strengthen their human, financial and physical capital. Through the establishment of communal nutrition gardens and the provision of training on food use, nutrition and hygiene, vulnerable families are better equipped to meet their own nutrition needs, with a specific focus on addressing the needs of the chronically ill.
